item.title: Boilers
item.description: Elaborating how it [[Chemistry/Water Treatment/Water#^743482|creates problems in boilers]] Sludge and Scale formation On continuous evaporation on hard water in boilers, the salts present in it get saturated and are finally deposited in the areas where the flow is slow.

item.title: Chemical Analysis of Water
item.description: Estimation of free chlorine Alkalinity Alkalinity is present due to OH⁻, CO₃⁻², HCO₃⁻ OH⁻ and HCO₃⁻ do not exist together If one is present the other can’t be: OH⁻+HCO₃⁻=CO₃²⁻+H₂O OH⁻ CO₃²⁻ [these two consist of P, for Phenolphthalein indicator] HCO₃⁻ [the above three consist of M, for Methyl orange indicator] Reactions: OH⁻+H⁺ → H₂O CO₃²⁻+H⁺ → HCO₃⁻ HCO₃⁻+H⁺ → H₂O+CO₂

item.title: Softening of Water
item.description: Removal of Calcium, magnesium, iron salts etc. to feed soft water into [[Chemistry/Water Treatment/Boilers|boilers]] Three processes Cold and Hot Lime soda process Only required amount of lime and soda are to be added to remove temporary and permanent hardness

item.title: Treatment for Domestic Use
item.description: Treatment for [[Chemistry/Water Treatment/Water#^1a9b58|domestic use]] Requirements for drinking water Clear and Odourless and devoid of unpleasant taste. Devoid of heavy metals and arsenic Free from pathogenic microorganisms pH~8 Suspended matter<10ppm Dissolved salts<500ppm Natural water treated for domestic use Aeration of raw water: passing compressed air to remove odour Sedimentation Settling in a large tang Adding coagulants (in the form of solution) for colloidal particles Alum: K₂SO₄ Green vitriol: FeSO₄ Precipitates contain Aluminium, ferrous, ferric hydroxides Bacteria Partially clarified water is filtered through sand gravity filters: rectangular tanks which contain fine layers of sand Sterilization 1.
